title: You know what is my biggest issue with the Star Guardian Skinline?
body:
They have no real antagonist besides some brainless monsters and occasionally one that seems a little more mean than the others. Ten shining heroes and... absolutely no one to oppose them? Sounds like a boring as hell narrative in the long run. If I were to use manga-comparisions (given the japanese nature of the theme) I'd say it's perfectly ok to let the protagonist fight mindless goons for the first ten to fifteen so chapters, but at some point you have to introduce the first proper villain, not necessarly the "big bad", not even really an underling of said "big bad", but just SOMEONE who can fight the protagonist on an even footing and who has some personality to them. 

I mean, you could also subvert the theme by having the magical heroes rip themselves apart in conflict, but a.) that has been done already b.) it was not necessarly something people wanted to see c.) it wouldn't really fit with the more "traditional" setting that the SG-Verse opens up. 

It can be other champions that get "villain" skins (maybe expand the Superb Villain skinline from just Veigar to an entire group of villains? League's own "Sinister Six" so to speak. Or get the SG-lore rolling with a comic and get your own out-of-game villains, I don't really care, JUST GET SOMETHING DONE ALREADY.

Heroes without villains are lame.

Imagine Batman without villains - he'd be some random rich dude, spending the day either brooding or venting his aggressions by beating up random ciminals who all pose absolutely no challange to him or his ideals. No one would really want to read that tbh...

The problem here is that we have a character-overload. Five protagonists can do just fine shredding random goons. But ten of them? Makes the mindless goons look absolutely useless, as they now get shredded twice as fast. Usually in the "fighting goons" stage you assemble the team, and then have it together to face the first villain. The mention of a secondary team often comes after that (mostly because they came to check out all the ruckus caused by the heroes beating the villain). Going by conventional dramaturgy we are missing at least one proper villain here...

Regarding character overload. If I were to guess...

I think we're going to see two conflict plot lines, one for Lux, one for Ahri.

Lux plot involves some threat to Earth that she and her team pursue and will have a traditional antagonist. From what I recall of the lore, Malzahar had a history of trying to meddle with the Void, so I could see him being the antagonist trying to open Gates, summon Void monsters, etc. Lux and team need to deal with him and his monsters/allies/henchmen. Lux and team will need to overcome this on their own. They could receive occasional help from Ahri, but Ahri and group are not going to play the role of saviors. See below...

The other line of conflict goes more into the history of the Star Guardians. This plot follows Ahri as she struggles against this notion of destiny and tries to find a way to keep Star Guardians from 'burning out'. An antagonist here could be someone further up the chain of command in the Star Guardian organization. I'm not prepared to make assumptions about who it could be. 

Sometimes the two teams work together, and sometimes their conflicting goals might put them at odds. They might find that their final goals overlap somehow, which would bring together all ten Star Guardians, but I think for the most part, they will operate as their individual teams with occasional overlap with one or two members of the other team.
This is how I see it too! Ahri is straight up like "Nah son, I do me, you do you" to Lux. But I don't think she's cold-hearted and would help Lux if Lux really needed it.
